A.levelDescription: Basic understanding of when and how to get help for substance-related concerns, and awareness of available support services.
whatYouWillLearn: When and why someone might need help with drugs or alcohol
Who can help and where to find support
What happens when you call a helpline or talk to a counsellor
How to help yourself or a friend in an emergency

explicatoryContent.heading: Recognising When Help is Needed
explicatoryContent.text: There are many reasons someone might need help related to drugs or alcohol. This could include feeling worried about your own use or someone else's use, experiencing negative effects from substances, being in an unsafe situation involving drugs, having questions you want answered, or just wanting someone to talk to. Needing help does not mean you are weak or bad - it means you are smart enough to reach out. Getting help early, before a problem becomes serious, is always better. Even if you are not sure whether you need help, it is okay to reach out and talk about what is happening.

explicatoryContent.heading: Who Can Help
explicatoryContent.text: Many people and services can provide help and support. Trusted adults like parents, guardians, relatives, teachers, or school counsellors can offer guidance and connect you with services. GPs (doctors) can provide confidential health advice and referrals. School wellbeing staff are trained to help students. Helplines like DirectLine (1800 888 236), Kids Helpline (1800 55 1800), and headspace (1800 650 890) provide free, confidential support over the phone, webchat, or text. You do not have to give your name when calling a helpline. These services are staffed by trained people who will not judge you. They can help whether you have a serious problem or just want information.

explicatoryContent.heading: What to Expect When Getting Help
explicatoryContent.text: If you call a helpline, a counsellor will answer and ask how they can help. You can share as much or as little as you want. They will listen, provide information, and help you think through your options. Everything you share is confidential (private) unless there is serious risk of harm to you or someone else. If you talk to a school counsellor or GP, they will ask questions to understand your situation. They might suggest strategies to try, connect you with other services, or book follow-up appointments. Remember, the person helping you is on your side - their job is to support you, not to get you in trouble. Getting help is a positive step.

explicatoryContent.heading: Emergency Situations
explicatoryContent.text: Some situations are emergencies that need immediate help. If someone is unconscious or cannot be woken up, having difficulty breathing, having a seizure, very confused or paranoid, or you are worried they might die, call 000 immediately. Tell the operator there is a medical emergency and describe what is happening. Stay with the person while waiting for help. If they are unconscious but breathing, place them in the recovery position (on their side). You will not get in trouble for calling for help in a medical emergency. In Australia, most states have laws protecting people who call for help during overdoses. Saving a life is always more important than worrying about getting in trouble.

B.levelDescription: Developing understanding of different types of help available, how to navigate support services, and how to effectively support others.
whatYouWillLearn: Different types of support services and when to use them
How to prepare for and navigate conversations about getting help
Strategies for supporting friends who may be struggling
Understanding barriers to help-seeking and how to overcome them

explicatoryContent.heading: Types of Support Services
explicatoryContent.text: Different services provide different types of help. Helplines offer immediate support, information, and referrals - they are a good first step when you are not sure where to turn. School counsellors and wellbeing staff can provide ongoing support and connect you with external services. GPs can assess health concerns, provide medical advice, and refer to specialists. headspace centres provide youth-friendly mental health and wellbeing support, including for substance use. Drug and alcohol services offer specialised assessment, counselling, and treatment. Some services are specifically for young people, others for families. Some are free, others have costs. Online services like chat counselling can be easier for some people than phone calls. Knowing what different services offer helps you find the right fit for your needs.

explicatoryContent.heading: Starting the Conversation
explicatoryContent.text: Talking about substance use concerns can feel difficult, but being prepared can help. Before reaching out, you might think about what you want to say and what you hope to achieve. You do not need to have all the answers - the person helping you will guide the conversation. You could start with something like 'I have been worried about...' or 'I have some questions about...' or 'Something happened and I need to talk to someone.' You can tell them how you would like them to help - just listen, give advice, or take action. If you are seeking help for yourself, remember that being honest helps the person support you better. If you try one service and it does not feel right, try another - finding the right fit sometimes takes a few attempts.

explicatoryContent.heading: Supporting a Friend
explicatoryContent.text: If you are worried about a friend's substance use, you can play an important support role. Choose a private time to express your concern without judgment. Focus on specific behaviours you have noticed rather than labels: 'I've noticed you've been drinking a lot lately' rather than 'You're an alcoholic.' Listen to their perspective - they may be dealing with things you do not know about. Offer to help them access support, like going with them to see a counsellor or helping them find a helpline number. Do not cover up for them or enable their use, but also do not issue ultimatums, as this often backfires. Set boundaries about what you can and cannot do - you cannot fix their problems, but you can be a supportive presence. If their safety is at risk, it is okay to involve an adult even if they do not want you to.

explicatoryContent.heading: Overcoming Barriers to Help-Seeking
explicatoryContent.text: Many things can make it hard to seek help. Stigma and shame - worrying about being judged or labelled - stop many people. Fear of consequences, like getting in trouble at school or with parents, is common. Not recognising that a problem exists, or minimising its severity, delays help-seeking. Practical barriers like not knowing where to go, transportation difficulties, or costs can prevent access to services. Some people worry that their information will not be kept confidential. Understanding these barriers helps us address them. Confidential services reduce fear of judgment. Knowing your rights and what to expect reduces fear of the unknown. Schools with supportive (rather than purely punitive) approaches encourage students to seek help. Campaigns to reduce stigma help normalise help-seeking as a sign of strength.

C.levelDescription: Sound understanding of treatment approaches, recovery processes, and the role of support systems in addressing substance use issues.
whatYouWillLearn: Different treatment approaches and how they work
The concept of recovery and what it involves
How families and support systems are affected and can help
The role of stigma in preventing help-seeking and how to challenge it

explicatoryContent.heading: Treatment Approaches
explicatoryContent.text: Various treatment approaches exist for substance use problems, and what works best varies by individual and situation. Brief interventions involve short conversations (often with a GP or counsellor) that provide feedback and advice to help people reduce or stop use. Counselling and therapy help people understand their use, develop coping strategies, and address underlying issues. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) identifies and changes unhelpful thought patterns and behaviours. Motivational interviewing helps people explore and resolve ambivalence about change. Family therapy involves family members in the treatment process. Residential treatment (rehabilitation) provides intensive support in a live-in setting for people with more serious problems. Medication-assisted treatment uses medications to manage withdrawal, reduce cravings, or block effects of substances. Treatment often involves multiple approaches and may need to be ongoing. Relapse (returning to use after a period of abstinence) is common and does not mean treatment has failed - it is often part of the recovery journey.

explicatoryContent.heading: Understanding Recovery
explicatoryContent.text: Recovery is the process of improving health and wellbeing, living a self-directed life, and striving to reach one's full potential. For some people, recovery means abstaining from all substance use. For others, it means reducing use to less harmful levels. Recovery is not just about stopping use - it involves building a meaningful life with positive relationships, purpose, and wellbeing. Recovery is a personal journey that looks different for everyone. It often involves setbacks and is rarely a straight line. Key elements that support recovery include having hope that change is possible, feeling connected to supportive people and communities, developing a sense of purpose and meaning, and building skills for managing challenges. Peer support from others who have experienced similar challenges can be particularly powerful. Recovery is possible at any stage, regardless of how long or serious someone's substance use has been.

explicatoryContent.heading: Impact on Families and Support Systems
explicatoryContent.text: Substance use problems affect not just the individual but their whole family and support network. Family members may experience a range of emotions including worry, frustration, anger, guilt, and grief. Relationships can become strained by broken trust, unpredictable behaviour, and conflict. Children in families affected by substance use may experience neglect, trauma, or instability. Some family members develop codependent patterns where their own wellbeing becomes entirely focused on the person using substances. However, families can also be powerful supports for recovery when they are healthy and informed. Family therapy helps family members understand addiction, improve communication, set healthy boundaries, and support recovery without enabling. Al-Anon and other family support groups provide peer support for people affected by someone else's drinking or drug use. Supporting a family member with substance use problems is stressful, and family members themselves need support and self-care.

explicatoryContent.heading: Challenging Stigma
explicatoryContent.text: Stigma - negative attitudes and discrimination against people with substance use problems - is one of the biggest barriers to help-seeking and recovery. Stigma comes from misunderstandings about addiction, including beliefs that it is simply a choice or moral failing rather than a complex health issue influenced by biology, environment, and circumstances. Stigma leads people to hide their struggles, avoid services, and face discrimination in employment, housing, and healthcare. Language matters: terms like 'addict,' 'junkie,' or 'substance abuser' are stigmatising, while person-first language like 'person with a substance use disorder' recognises humanity beyond the condition. Media portrayals often reinforce stereotypes. Challenging stigma involves educating ourselves and others, using respectful language, treating people with compassion, and supporting policies that address substance use as a health issue. People with lived experience of substance use and recovery are powerful voices for reducing stigma.

D.levelDescription: Comprehensive understanding of the evidence base for treatment and recovery, service systems, and the intersection of substance use with broader health and social issues.
whatYouWillLearn: The evidence base for different treatment approaches
How service systems are organised and gaps that exist
The connections between substance use and mental health
Principles of trauma-informed care and how they apply

explicatoryContent.heading: Evidence-Based Treatment
explicatoryContent.text: Treatment effectiveness varies by substance, individual characteristics, and treatment fidelity. For alcohol use disorder, cognitive behavioural therapy, motivational enhancement therapy, and twelve-step facilitation all show effectiveness. Medications like naltrexone and acamprosate can support abstinence. For opioid use disorder, medication-assisted treatment with methadone, buprenorphine, or naltrexone is strongly evidence-based and significantly reduces mortality. For cannabis use disorder, no medications are currently approved, and psychosocial treatments (CBT, motivational interviewing, contingency management) are primary approaches. Residential treatment can be appropriate for severe cases but is not inherently more effective than outpatient treatment. Treatment matching - fitting approaches to individual needs - improves outcomes. Aftercare and ongoing support are important for maintaining gains. The effectiveness of self-help groups like Alcoholics Anonymous is debated; they work well for some but not all. A key principle is that some treatment is better than none, and treatment often needs to be tried multiple times before it 'sticks.'

explicatoryContent.heading: Service System Organisation
explicatoryContent.text: In Australia, alcohol and other drug services are delivered through a mix of public, private, and non-government organisations. State and territory governments fund most public AOD services. The Medicare Benefits Schedule covers some treatment through GPs and psychiatrists. Private health insurance covers some private rehabilitation. Non-government organisations (NGOs) deliver many community services. Services range from information and brief intervention through to intensive residential treatment. Pathways include GP referral, self-referral to community services, hospital emergency departments, and the justice system. Gaps in the system include long wait times for some services, limited services in rural and remote areas, limited youth-specific services, and challenges accessing services for people with co-occurring mental health conditions. Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations provide culturally appropriate services for First Nations communities. Understanding how services are organised helps with navigating the system and advocating for improvements.

explicatoryContent.heading: Co-occurring Mental Health Conditions
explicatoryContent.text: Substance use and mental health problems commonly co-occur - this is called comorbidity or dual diagnosis. Estimates suggest that around half of people with substance use disorders also have a mental health condition, and vice versa. The relationship is complex: mental health problems can lead to substance use as people try to self-medicate; substance use can trigger or worsen mental health conditions; common underlying factors (like trauma or genetics) can contribute to both; and each condition can make the other harder to treat. Historically, mental health and AOD services operated separately, meaning people with both issues fell through gaps. Integrated treatment that addresses both conditions together is now recognised as best practice, though implementation varies. For young people, early identification and treatment of both mental health and substance use issues is particularly important as adolescence is a key period for the development of both.

explicatoryContent.heading: Trauma-Informed Care
explicatoryContent.text: Trauma-informed care (TIC) is an approach that recognises the widespread impact of trauma and integrates this understanding into all aspects of service delivery. Many people with substance use problems have experienced trauma - including childhood abuse and neglect, family violence, accidents, or other traumatic events. Trauma affects the brain and body in ways that can contribute to substance use as a coping mechanism. Traditional approaches that involve confrontation, strip searches, or punitive responses can be retraumatising. TIC principles include realising the prevalence and impact of trauma, recognising signs of trauma, responding by integrating trauma knowledge into policies and practices, and resisting retraumatisation. TIC emphasises safety (physical and emotional), trustworthiness, choice, collaboration, and empowerment. TIC is not a specific treatment but a framework that shapes how all services are delivered. This approach is particularly relevant for services working with young people, who may have experienced adverse childhood experiences that affect their health trajectories.

E.levelDescription: Advanced critical analysis of recovery science, treatment systems, and the sociopolitical context of addiction treatment, with capacity for advocacy and systems thinking.
whatYouWillLearn: Emerging research in recovery science and what supports long-term recovery
Critical analysis of treatment philosophies and their evidence base
The political economy of addiction treatment and barriers to evidence-based care
Skills for advocacy and contributing to system improvement

explicatoryContent.heading: Recovery Science
explicatoryContent.text: Recovery science is an emerging field studying the process, pathways, and predictors of recovery from substance use disorders. Large-scale studies have identified factors associated with sustained recovery: recovery capital (resources that support recovery including social, physical, human, and cultural capital), meaningful activities and sense of purpose, positive social connections and community involvement, stable housing and income, good physical and mental health, and hope and self-efficacy. The Recovery Capital Index measures these factors. Research on recovery trajectories shows considerable heterogeneity - some people recover quickly without formal treatment (natural recovery), others through treatment, others through self-help groups, and many through combinations. Long-term studies suggest that most people with substance use disorders eventually recover, challenging the view of addiction as a chronic relapsing condition. Recovery-oriented systems of care shift focus from acute treatment episodes to long-term support for recovery. Peer recovery support - people with lived experience providing support - is increasingly recognised as valuable.

explicatoryContent.heading: Critical Analysis of Treatment Philosophies
explicatoryContent.text: Different treatment philosophies reflect different understandings of addiction and recovery. The disease model views addiction as a chronic brain disease requiring lifelong abstinence and involvement in twelve-step programs. Evidence supports some aspects (neurobiological changes, genetic components) but not the necessity of lifelong identification as an 'addict' or exclusive abstinence. Harm reduction views substance use on a continuum and aims to reduce harms without requiring abstinence as a precondition. Evidence strongly supports harm reduction approaches, though they remain politically controversial. The biopsychosocial model integrates biological, psychological, and social factors. Recovery models emphasise personal agency, hope, and holistic wellbeing beyond just stopping use. Critiques of medicalisation argue that framing addiction as a disease can reduce stigma but also obscure social determinants and political-economic factors. Critical addiction studies examine how race, class, gender, and colonialism shape addiction patterns and treatment access. Thoughtful practitioners integrate insights from multiple perspectives rather than rigidly adhering to one philosophy.

explicatoryContent.heading: Political Economy of Addiction Treatment
explicatoryContent.text: Addiction treatment exists within political, economic, and cultural contexts that shape its availability, quality, and orientation. Political ideologies influence whether addiction is framed as a health issue (requiring treatment) or a moral/criminal issue (requiring punishment). Funding decisions reflect these ideologies - investment in treatment versus incarceration. The private treatment industry, worth billions globally, has financial interests that may not always align with evidence-based care. Some high-profile residential programs charge enormous fees despite limited evidence of superiority over outpatient alternatives. Pharmaceutical companies influence which treatments are promoted. Insurance coverage shapes which services people can access. Drug scheduling and prohibition affect what treatments are legal and available. Social factors like racism, poverty, and housing instability affect both who develops substance use problems and who can access quality treatment. Advocacy for better treatment requires understanding these political-economic dimensions and engaging with policy processes. Young people can be powerful advocates because substance use policies directly affect their generation.

explicatoryContent.heading: Advocacy and System Change
explicatoryContent.text: Improving treatment and recovery support requires advocacy at multiple levels. Individual advocacy might involve supporting someone to navigate services and assert their rights. Community advocacy could include challenging local barriers to service access or reducing stigma through education campaigns. Policy advocacy addresses systemic issues like funding, regulations, and program design. Effective advocacy involves identifying clear goals, understanding decision-making processes, building coalitions with allies, gathering and presenting evidence, engaging media strategically, and persisting over time. Principles include centring the voices of people with lived experience, using respectful and destigmatising language, engaging with rather than demonising those who hold different views, and balancing critique with constructive alternatives. Youth engagement in advocacy builds civic skills and can shift narratives that often exclude young voices. Areas where advocacy is needed include expanding youth-specific services, increasing access in rural areas, implementing harm reduction approaches, addressing co-occurring conditions, and shifting from punishment to health-based responses.
